title: Viral & Chlamydial Conjunctivitis: The Complete Clinical Compendium
summary: An exhaustive guide to identifying and managing viral and chlamydial infections of the conjunctiva. This poster covers everything from Adenoviral serotypes and Keratitis stages to the WHO Trachoma classification and SAFE strategy.

sections.title: Adenoviral Clinical Features
content: Symptoms: Watering, burning, itching ± photophobia/blurred vision (if keratitis)

sections.title: The Three Stages of Keratitis
content: Stage 3 (d11 onwards): Subepithelial opacities (may last years; non-staining)

sections.title: Adenoviral Management
content: Investigation: Conjunctival swabs (viral transport medium) for viral antigen determination or PCR
Supportive: Cool compresses and artificial tears
Antibiotics: ± Topical antibiotics (supposedly to prevent 2° bacterial infection)
Steroids: Some authors advocate low-dose topical steroids if subepithelial opacities affect vision
Steroid Risk: Opacities recur on cessation; encourages long-term steroid dependency

sections.title: Spread Prevention Protocol
content: Wash hands and clean equipment before the next patient
Follow-up if condition worsens or persists after treatment

sections.title: Molluscum Contagiosum
sections.content:
This dsDNA virus of the pox virus group is common in children/young adults; profuse lesions are seen with HIV infection or severe immunosuppression. Transmission is by close contact. The lesions may be missed if buried in the lash margin. Shedding of viral particles from the lesion may cause persistent follicular conjunctivitis.

Clinical features: Chronic history; pearly, umbilicated nodule at lid margin; mucoid discharge; follicles.

Treatment: Remove the lid lesion (e.g. cryotherapy, cauterization, shave excision, expression).

sections.title: Herpes Simplex (Type 1)
content: Blepharokeratoconjunctivitis: Usually a 1° infection of this dsDNA virus
Clinical Features: Burning, FB sensation; unilateral follicular conjunctivitis
BNF Recommendation: Treat until 3d after complete healing
If keratitis: Treat accordingly (refer to pp. 258–9/262–3)

sections.title: Other Viral Causes
content: Other members of the herpes group

branches: Reticular body: Obligate intracellular reproductive stage
Replicates within host cell (seen as inclusion body)

sections.title: Adult Inclusion Conjunctivitis
content: Transmission: Almost always sexually transmitted (occasional eye-to-eye)
Demographics: Most common in young adults (♂ > ♀)
Laterality: Usually unilateral (but may be bilateral)
Signs: Mucopurulent discharge, lid oedema ± ptosis, follicles (papillae initially)
Localization: Usually most severe on superior tarsus and bulbar conjunctiva
Keratitis: Punctate epithelial erosions, subepithelial opacities, marginal infiltrates

sections.title: Inclusion Conjunctivitis: Management
content: Investigation: Firmly swab superior tarsus for immunofluorescent staining, culture, PCR, or ELISA
Referral: Refer to GU clinic for assessment, treatment, and contact tracing
First line Systemic: Azithromycin 1g stat OR Doxycycline 100mg 2×/d for 1wk

branches: C. trachomatis serotypes A, B, Ba, and C

rows: Tarsal inflammation sufficient to obscure >50% of tarsal vessels
Corneal opacity involving at least part of the pupillary margin

content.explanation: S: Surgery (for in-turned eyelashes), A: Antibiotics (for active disease), F: Face washing (promotion of facial cleanliness), E: Environmental improvement (to reduce transmission)

sections.title: Trachoma Clinical Features
content: Follicular reaction: More marked in upper rather than lower lid
Arlt lines: On the superior tarsus (scarring)
Herbert pits: Limbal follicles that have scarred

sections.title: Trachoma Investigation & Treatment
content: Acute Investigations: Swabs for immunofluorescent staining, culture, PCR, or ELISA

sections.title: Note on Neonatal Infections
sections.content: For Neonatal chlamydial conjunctivitis, see E Ophthalmia neonatorum, pp. 882–3. WHO aims to eliminate trachoma as a blinding disease by 2020.
